Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 01:55PM mckenna wrote: get another opinion.  it can't hurt and two might agree then you might find it easier to decide.  i had to have a wire placed for my lumpectomy and i can honestly say i felt no pain.  not even the needle they used to numb the area, it was very uneventful (comparatively speaking). i know that is not everyone's experience but it was mine.  good luck
Posts.Title: Radiologist and Surgeon Disagree LisaDVM Shayne

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 09:32AM mckenna wrote: i had an mri and mri guided biopsy.  neither was painful.  both were uncomfortable because you have to remain so still for 45min-an hour.  i will continue to have mri's yearly as that is how my cancer was found at the age of 38. i think i am going to ask for something to relax me next time, it would just make things easier.  you do get an iv prior to the mri so that contrast can be admisisterd half way through mri.  good luck and hoping for b9 results
Posts.Title: 44 and Scared 44andscared Kareywith3littlekittens

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 06:19PM mckenna wrote: i am 36, i have been having bloody nipple discharge from my left breast.  i went to my ob/gyn who sent me for a mammogram and ultrasound.  both were clear so they sent me to a breast surgeon.  they did another mammo and us.  both are still clear but i have to have a ductal excision in 3 weeks.  initially you could see the blood coming from one spot but this am it appeared like it was coming from 2 spots i dont know how that will change things.  i am scheduled for a ductogram at 8am and the surgery at 9:30 that same day.  i am being told that ductal excision is the only option for ductal papilomas.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Mammogram After Discovering Bloody Discharge dido1 leaf

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 07:10AM mckenna wrote: melinda, your post was amazing.  i had a breast cancer scare at the end of september and i literally could not have the radio on in the car because if i heard one more advertisement for breast cancer awareness month or pink merchandise, i thought i was going to loose it.  as it is i did not have breast cancer but i do have adh, and the whole pinktober is too much for me. i was so glad to read here on these boards that some woman who are diagnosed feel the same as me.  i thought there was something wrong with me, that i could not embrace the pink move.  thanks to you and others who share your feelings about "pinking" so that woman like me don't feel like we are some how wrong for not embracing the pink movement.
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2012 12:05PM mckenna wrote: surrounding tissue was removed from my ductal excision for an intraductal papilloma.  that is how my adh was found.  no cancer was found at that time.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 12:29PM mckenna wrote: surgery went smoothly, i am taking the pain meds every 4 hours but think i am going to start tapering them off.  "school lunch" ice packs work great and the zip front sports bras are perfect.  i can take the gauze off tonight and shower tomorrow night so that will make me feel much better.  the kids are with my mom and dad so i am getting some rest.  now to wait for the results i have a follow up appointment on thursday, so i assume i will know more then.  thanks for listening

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 02:35PM mckenna wrote: forgot to say if you are being treated at a teaching hospital, be sure to request that the attending does the ductogram.  it is not a very common test and when i had mine, come to find out these 2 residents that wanted to do it had never even seen one much less done one.  luckily it has always been my policy of no students in the room and only attendings touching me :)  i have never been stuck more than once for anything having attendings do everything
Posts.Title: Galactograph next.. yikes! tinaweena tinaweena

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2012 02:53PM mckenna wrote: it is also called a ductogram.  i had one prior to my papiloma/ductal excision.  truely i did not feel anything.  it sort of felt full once they injected the dye.  they did the excision immediately following the ductogram.  my papilloma could not be detected on a mammogram or ultrasound but when they did the ductogram they were able to see it and then the surgeon could remove it.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 01:46PM mckenna wrote: in the past 18 months i have had 10 mammograms, 2 ultra sounds and 2 mri's.  the firs ultrasound i had was the most painful of any of the tests.  i don't know what that woman was looking for but she pushed so hard it brought tears to my eyes.  then i got referred to our cancer center and someone that seemed to be much more knowledgeable did the ultra sound and it was a piece of cake.  i can honestly say i have not had pain or even felt undignified at any mammo.  i have larger breasts and have heard that it is less uncomfortable for larger breasted women.  i don't know if there is any truth to that.  good luck and remember these women do mammos day in and day out tell them your concerns, they will work with you.
Posts.Title: My first mammogram RaptorSqueaks omg333

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 03:29PM mckenna wrote: crazy huh!  between diagnostic and pre surgeries and post biopsies and checking for infection after surgery......
Posts.Title: My first mammogram RaptorSqueaks omg333

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 11:20AM mckenna wrote: have you asked your bs about breast mri. i had duct removed 18 months ago. i have been getting mammos every 6 months to get me to once a year and the nurse practitioner ordered an mri due to the adh and on the very first mri, a very small spot lit up, i had an mri guided biosy that actually removed the whole tumor (when had lumpectomy there was ned). i was diagnosed with dcis that had not been seen on the mammo 6 months earlier. if you have adh, i highly recommend talking about an mri with your bs. good luck.
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 11:00AM mckenna wrote: i wish i would have just slowed everything down.  i felt like my surgeon had an idea of what the wanted me to do and did not give me a lot of options and rushed me to surgery.  the best advice i can give you is to trust your gut.  it is a lot of info to take in and if somthing just doesn't set right, get a second opinion.  i have switched surgeons since my surgery and the new BS says she tests all women under 40 for brac.  she tested me right there in the office, i have to wait 4 weeks for the results but i wich i had had those results before moving forward with anything. however hind sight is 20/20.  take some one with you, write down your questions and have the person with you write down the answers to the questions.
Posts.Title: Any advice for my first meeting with surgeon? ElleBee stickwitch28

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 04:46PM mckenna wrote: i was diagnosed with adh in sept/oct of 2010.  my surgeon did not recommend even seeing a medical oncologist and i changed nothing.  i was however followed by his wonderful nurse practitioner that orded an mri  in march of this year (even though all mammos and ultrasounds had been clear).  mri found a very small spot of dcis.  i had a lumpectomy that showed no evidence of disease as the mri biobsy had actually removed all of the cancer.  if the infection from my lumpectomy (infection is nowhere near the incision site but on the same boob and no one can really tell me what is causing it) ever clears up  i will start 5 weeks of rads next week and then 5 years of tamoxifen.  i don't tell you this to scare you, just so that you are being proactive with your medical team and make sure they are following you closely and referring you to the right specialists.  i wish i had demanded a referral to a med onc at my adh diagnosis. i am not sure she would have changed the treatment for adh, but now i will never know. i am only 38 so i am being treated more aggressively than some with a DCIS diagnosis.  now since the diagnosis, i am really watching what i am eating and trying not to eat too much meat.  i want to get into a good exersice routine but it is hard with this infection and now i am afraid to sweat because i don't want the radiaion marks wearing off any more eaisly than they already are.  all the things you are mentioning were things recommended to me by my MO after the diagnosis, i wish i would have done these things after the adh diag.  good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 04:38PM mckenna wrote: i had an mri and mri biobsy.  you lay the same as you did for the mri but there is a grid type thing that is in both sides of the boob that tells them where to insert the needle.  i felt little to no pain the hardest part was laying still.  good luck
Posts.Title: Mammogram/Ultrasound/Core biopsies today websister proudtospin

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 03:21AM mckenna wrote: My gyn sent me to a breast surgeon as soon as I saw her for the bloody nipple discharge (in 2010). When I saw him he said I needed surgery to remove the papilloma but said that the ductogram should be done the morning of surgery. (My mammogram and ultra sound did not show the papilloma but the ductogram did.) He said that if it were just a papilloma with clear pathology I would go back to seeing gyn yearly and wouldn't need mammogram until age 40. That is the typical outcome. For me my pathology showed adh which made the breast surgeon follow me more closely. The nipple discharge is the common symptom of papillomas and most are b9.
Posts.Title: Waiting & oh so very scared... jeaandrla627 carolliin

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 09:54AM mckenna wrote: jayega, i really do not like to exercise so right now while other issues are going on, i am walking 30 minutes a day.  my kids have to be at school at 7:45 and i don't have to be to work till 8:30.  it only takes 15 minutes to get to my office so i drive there, park my car and walk from 8-8:30 in our down town area.  i try not to sweat because i have to go to work so it is not a huge cardiovasular exercise time but before i used to sit at my desk and read or surg the internet so i figure it is at least a start :)

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 11:03AM mckenna wrote: i think it may be the margin issue.  the pathology report from my lumpectomy was no evidence of disease.  the enitre spot of DCIS was removed with the initial biopsy so there were no margin issues as there was no cancer left at time of lumpectomy.  i am only 38 so that is why the RO recommended full breast rads to begin with.
Posts.Title: no boosts mckenna Mopsy

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2012 11:22AM mckenna wrote: Hi Bl :) i likely have truncal lymphedema (even without nodes removed) i had it prior ot radiaion but my pt told me that radiation can cause it, but there is obvious swelling (imprint of sports bra after i take it off, etc).  i too am in constant pain/irritation but mine is mostly the boob and under arm. i just started with a physical therapist.  i have good range of motion in my shoulder.  i think i would request a referral to a pt/lymph specialist. they will evaluate you and see if further treatment is necessary.  i get those stabbing pains sometimes too but no chest wall pain.  good luck, let us know how things are going
